text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Friday.
- Croatia gets its first 200 million German marks loan from commercial creditors and arranged by Dresdner Bank.
- Who will get 500,000 sq m property of the former communist party and other political bodies from the previous regime which under a new law belong to the state?
- Most car insurers in Croatia extend invalid policies, state control board said after a brief probe. Maplractices are mostly based on unfounded discounts.
- Hotelier faculty in Pula hosts "Hotel House", a two day international congress of over 200 experts.
- Inland revenue threatens to denounce companies which might unfoundedly raise prices once VAT is imposed in January.
- Trade unions propose a 1,100 kuna non taxable salary base in negotiations with the government.
- Parliamentary speaker Vlatko Pavletic agrees with the opposition, boycotting parliament sessions protesting over lack of media coverage.
- After admission to the Council of Europe, lawyers to become the busiest in Croatia as many laws need adjustment to comply with European conventions.
- Parliament discusses a draft law on trades and small enterprises which now employ some 84,000 people, 50 percent more than in 1991.
- Minister Niko Bulic says tourism would yield 10 million kuna by the end of 1996, but the tourist trade may end the year with a zero profit. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
